Rational degeneration of a Tate spectral sequence

Jun 28, 2020

In this post, I would like to discuss a noncommutative analogue of the rational degeneration of the slope spectral sequence in crystalline cohomology.

Let be a perfect field of characteristic , let be the ring of Witt vectors, and let denote its fraction field. Recall from here that a -typical topological Cartier module is an -spectrum with an -equivariant factorization

of the norm, where and are given the -action via the -fold covering . If is a -typical cyclotomic spectrum, then is a -typical topological Cartier module.

Let be a -typical topological Cartier module. Then is a graded module over the ring , where and are in degree , and are in degree zero, and is the ideal of relations

A graded module over is called a -typical Cartier complex.

Theorem: Let be a perfect -module in -typical topological Cartier modules such that is -complete. Then the Tate spectral sequence

degenerates rationally (i.e., modulo -power torsion).

The differential in the Tate spectral sequence is of bidegree , and so is nonzero only when is even; in that case,

Since the slopes of on lie in , and the slopes of lies in , it suffices to observe that preserves slopes, i.e., that . (This follows from the fact that acts on by .) This implies that vanishes, since , as desired.

The proof of this theorem shows:

Corollary: Let denote the sub--isocrystal of on which the slopes of satisfy . Then there is an isomorphism

So, for instance, suppose is a smooth and proper -linear stable -category such that is -complete. By Corollary 5 here, is a perfect -module, so we can apply the theorem and corollary to this example.
